subSections.title: Glyph origin
subSections.text:
{{Han etym}}
{{Han compound|宀|呂|ls=ic}}: many rooms under a roof (a palace).

subSections.title: Definitions
Usage notes
subSections.text: In reference to temples, 宮 ("palace") is used for {{w|Chinese folk religion|traditional deities}} considered to rank highly in the celestial bureaucracy, such as {{w|Mazu}} who was honored by the {{w|Qing dynasty}} as the "Queen of Heaven" after their successful {{w|Qing conquest of Taiwan|invasion of Taiwan}}.

subSections.title: Compounds
Etymology 1
Noun
subSections.text:
{{ja-noun|みや}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=みや|Shinto}} the place where a god resides: a [[shrine]]
#* {{RQ:Nippo Jisho|413}}<ref name="NJ">{{R:Nippo Jisho}}</ref>
#*: '''Miya'''. ミヤ (宮) 神 (Camis)の社.
# {{lb|ja|sort=みや|Buddhism}} a [[temple]] holding a Buddhist statue
# the place where a ruler resides: a [[palace]]
#* {{RQ:Nippo Jisho|413}}<ref name="NJ"/>
#*: '''Miya'''. ミヤ (宮) 国王の子. また, 国王の宮殿
# a member of the imperial family
#* {{RQ:Nippo Jisho|413}}<ref name="NJ"/>
#*: '''Miya'''. ミヤ (宮) 国王の子. また, 国王の宮殿

subSections.title: Proper noun
Etymology 2
subSections.text:
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|きゅう}}
From {{bor|ja|ltc|-|sort=きゅう}} {{m|zh|宮|tr=kjuwng||dwelling; palace; note on a scale}}. Compare modern {{cog|nan|-}} reading ''kiong''.
